## Publication History

Brave New World is a dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931, and published in 1932.(no content)Huxley wrote Brave New World while living in Sanary-sur-Mer, France, in the four months from May to August 1931.(no content)Brave New World enjoyed great success, both commercially and critically, when it was first published. It sold over 23,000 copies during its first two years on the market, and it was, for the most part, lauded by reviewers.

## International Publication and Translations

The search results provide some specific information about translations:

### French Translation
Translations of the title often allude to similar expressions used in domestic works of literature: the French edition of the work is entitled Le Meilleur des mondes (The Best of All Worlds), an allusion to an expression used by the philosopher Gottfried Leibniz and satirised in Candide, Ou l'Optimisme by Voltaire (1759).

### Chinese Translation
The first Standard Chinese translation, done by novelist Lily Hsueh and Aaron Jen-wang Hsueh in 1974, is entitled "美麗新世界" (Pinyin: Měilì Xīn Shìjiè, literally "Beautiful New World").

## Critical Reception and Legacy

Upon its publication, Rebecca West praised Brave New World as "The most accomplished novel Huxley has yet written", Joseph Needham lauded it as "Mr Huxley's remarkable book", and Bertrand Russell also praised it. However, Brave New World also received negative responses from other contemporary critics, although his work was later embraced. The reception of Brave New World at its publication was primarily negative. Many were offended by the nature of Huxley's future, and very few understood the novel's philosophical implications.(no content)In 1998 and 1999, the Modern Library ranked Brave New World at number 5 on its list of the 100 Best Novels in English of the 20th century.
